awd_titl_txt: Quantifying the Invasive Grass-Fire Cycle and Implications for Carbon Storage in the Continental U.S.
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will investigate how non-native, invasive grasses alter fire regimes and carbon storage across a range of ecosystems in the continental U.S.  By exploring how invasive grasses impact wildfire, the project will expand basic understanding of how invasive species affect the ways in which ecosystems function.  By quantifying changes in carbon stocks associated with invasion and fire, the project will provide a national estimate of how the grass-fire cycle affects ecosystem carbon storage.  The project will benefit society by quantifying wildfire risks associated with fire-prone invasive grasses.  By highlighting the previously neglected carbon costs of invasive grasses and associated wildfires, this project also will provide new perspectives, insights, and information regarding the management and control of fire-prone invasive grasses.

One of the most adverse ecological consequences of non-native grass invasion is the alteration of fire regimes.  The addition of invasive fuels increases fire frequency and impedes the recovery of native ecosystems.  The invasion of non-native species and altered fire regimes affect land-cover types ranging from deserts to prairies to forests.  Although dozens of fire-prone grasses have invaded throughout the continental U.S., cheatgrass (Bromus tectorum) remains the only species for which a regional grass-fire cycle has been quantified, and the carbon consequences of ecological change associate with altered fire related to invasive grasses has been measured only for this same species.  The investigators conducting this project will study how invasive grasses are altering regional fire cycles and how these changes affect carbon stocks in the continental U.S.  They will combine a comprehensive database of fire-prone invasive grass occurrence locations with fire data gathered using satellite-based moderate-resolution imaging spectroradiometer (MODIS) and visible infrared imaging radiometer suite (VIIRS) sensors to identify invasive grasses that are altering regional fire cycles.  They will model the potential range of grass infestations using parameter-elevation relationships on independent slopes model (PRISM) climate data, shuttle radar topography mission (SRTM) topography data, and MODIS and U.S. Geological Survey phenology vegetation products as predictors.  The investigators will quantify changes in above- and below-ground biomass and soil carbon stocks associated with grass invasion using a combination of field measurements for three target species and literature reviews for other known invasive grass species, and they will scale-up these site-level measurements of carbon loss using the distribution data and potential range models to calculate the carbon consequences of the grass-fire cycle.  Through integration of these four related project components, the investigators will provide new insights regarding the connections among invasive grasses, fire, and the carbon cycle.

por.por_cntn:
By exploring how pervasive the invasive grass-fire cycle is across multiple species in the U.S., we tested theoretical predictions about introduced species’ ability to alter ecosystem functioning. We quantified the consequences of the grass-fire cycle for carbon cycling for two well-known and problematic invasive grasses (cheatgrass and buffelgrass). Exploring the connection between invasive grasses, fire, and the carbon cycle advances our understanding of how human activities alter fundamental environmental processes. Our research addressed the overarching questions: How are invasive grasses altering regional fire cycles, and how do these changes affect carbon stocks in the continental U.S.? 

The research supported by this project documented a significant relationship between non-native, invasive grasses and an increase in fire frequency and size across ecosystems of the U.S.  For two prominent fire-prone invasive grasses (cheatgrass in the Great Basin Desert and buffelgrass in the Sonoran Desert), our work shows that invasion leads to a decrease in aboveground and soil carbon storage, an effect that is further exacerbated by fire.  Using a case study for cheatgrass, we showed that grass percent cover is linearly related to biomass (and aboveground carbon storage), enabling a direct link between remotely sensed products of invasive grass cover to carbon accounting.  Lastly, our work highlights the importance of the human component in both invasion and fire.  We showed that current state policies prohibiting the sale of invasive plants do little to consistently prevent the spread of invasive grasses.  In a review article, we also showed that humans not only introduce invasive grasses, but also ignite most grass fires to perpetuate the grass-fire cycle.

This research resulted in seven scientific publications, with an additional two publications in progress. The work trained three undergraduate students, two PhD students, and two postdoctoral researchers. We informed invasive plant managers about the grass-fire cycle through outreach via the Northeast and North Central Regional Invasive Species & Climate Change (RISCC) Management Networks.  Our research results were covered by several major media outlets. We wrote blog posts, gave public presentations, and engaged classrooms to talk about invasions and fire.
